data.title: Astoria: 20 reasons to love Oregon's historic city on the Columbia River
data.meta_description: Oregon's oldest Euro-American settlement, Astoria at the mouth of the Columbia River has lots of great things going for it. Here are 20 things to love about Astoria.
data.text:
Alex Pajunas/Courtesy of The Daily Astorian/2009

Astoria: 20 things we love about Oregon's first city

The Astoria-Megler Bridge, with clouds hanging on the Washington side of the Columbia River, is an Oregon icon. Keep clicking for more of why we love Astoria.

Also, each slide has a link to a report from my recent travel project on Astoria and its neighbors. I'm also doing another Oregon coast project this year.

Straff photo/2006

No. 1: History

Pacific Northwest Living Historians playing members of the Lewis and Clark Expedition march out of the newly rebuilt Fort Clatsop during the Return of the Fort dedication ceremony. Astoria takes its history seriously.

Plan your Astoria visit at travelastoria.com.

Randy L. Rasmussen/Staff/2014

No. 2: The column

A visitor launches a balsa wood airplane off the top of the Astoria Column, a local tradition from the landmark atop Coxcomb Hill. The column has a commanding view of the Columbia River.

Terry Richard/Staff/2014

No. 3: Sunday Market

Astoria Sunday Market is a big community block party downtown, featuring dog-friendly shopping that starts up again Mothers Day Weekend.

Terry Richard/Staff/2014

No. 4: Brewing up a storm

Astoria takes its beer seriously, especially at Fort George Brewery, located downtown in an old auto dealership. This is the taproom. There are multiple parts of the public house for dining and relaxing.

Terry Richard/Staff/2014

No. 5: Saddle up and hike

Saddle Mountain, the high point of Clatsop County at 3,283 feet, has a hiking trail to the summit in Saddle Mountain State Natural Area that just might knock your socks off.

Terry Richard/Staff/2007

No. 6: Can't get much saltier

Columbia River Maritime Museum has a U.S. Coast Guard rescue boat display. Look for the museum across the highway from the lunch line at the Bowpicker.

Staff photo/2007

No. 7: Good at romance, too

The waterfront Cannery Pier Hotel, with backdrop of the Astoria-Megler Bridge, was recently named a top 25 hotel for romance by tripadvisor.com.

Terry Richard/Staff/2014

No. 8: Downtown improvements

The Garden of Surging Waves across from City Hall has improved part of a downtown block, with more to come right next door.

Staff photo/2013

No. 9: It's a show stopper

The refurbished Liberty Theater is a fresh home for performing arts in downtown Astoria, drawing some pretty big names to entertain because everyone wants to visit Astoria in summer.

Terry Richard/Staff/2014

No. 10: It's Oregon's cruise port

The American Empress, in port in Astoria on the river behind the Columbia River Maritime Museum, cruises the Columbia River to Clarkston, Wash., but Astoria also is the only Oregon city called on regularly by ocean-going cruise ships.

Plan your Astoria visit at travelastoria.com.

Staff photo/2013

No. 11: Fine dining run amok

Meredith Adamson serves fresh halibut at Clemente's, acclaimed for its cuisine and the ethic of sustainable, locally-produced ingredients. The restaurant and four others spilt the reader vote for best fine dining is Astoria.

Clemente's has reolated to 14th Street Pilot Station building on the Astoria Riverwalk.

Terry Richard/Staff/April 17, 2015

No. 12: Wild about wildlife

One way or the other, the California sea lions basking on the Port of Astoria docks in the East Mooring Basin stir the emotions of residents and visitors alike.

Staff photo/2012

No. 13: It's an eventful place

Jay Speakman (left) of Gearhart and Jon Broderick of Cannon Beach perform at Baked Alaska during the annual Fisher Poets Gathering in February at Astoria, which hosts a number of big events throughout the year to entertain locals and visitors.

Coming April 25-26 is the Astoria Crab, Seafood and Wine Festival, one of the biggest of all.

Staff photo/2013

No. 14: Did the Queen live here?

Astoria has many Victorian and Queen Anne-style houses, inclucing the Flavel House that is preserved as a living museum by the Clatsop County Historical Society.

Staff photo/2006

No. 15: Fort Stevens is close by

Wreck of the Peter Iredale in Fort Stevens State Park near Warrenton is a short drive away from Astoria, in case you want to catch a sunset.

Staff photo/2013

No. 16: Pier 39 anchors east end

Pier 39 is at the east end of Astoria's riverside hiking and biking trail. It was built as the old Bumble Bee fish cannery and is now home to a museum, kayak rental, coffeeshop and Rogue Ales Pub.

Terry Richard/Staff/2014

No. 17: Ride the trolley

Explore the waterfront either by hopping off and on the Astoria Trolley, or do the Riverwalk.

Staff photo/2013

No. 18: Do the Voodoo

Get down in the Voodoo Room, an icon of retro hipness in downtown Astoria, or check out its companion businesses, the Columbian Cafe and Columbian moviehouse, both also local cult classics.

Staff photo/2013

No. 19: It doesn't stop with coffee

Sharon Collyer serves fresh fish tacos among the favorites at the Astoria Coffeehouse Bistro, which has expanded its menu way beyond morning coffee.

Staff photo/2013

No. 20: It may have been filmed here

The Oregon Film Museum is located in the old county jail, inviting visitors to make their own movie on sets inspired by the 1984 cult classic, "Goonies," filmed in Astoria.

Plan your Astoria getaway at travelastoria.com.

Thomas Boyd/Staff/2010

Don't forget Seaside

Riders strap in for a ride on the carousel at the Seaside Carousel Mall on Broadway Street, in Seaside, a family fun zone only 17 miles south of Astoria.

Terry Richard/Staff/2007

And Cannon Beach, too

Cannon Beach, with its famous Haystack Rock, offers upscale visitor amenities in a laid back Oregon coast setting, 25 miles south of Astoria. And don't forget to visit the beach, after you've seen the many galleries.

Terry Richard/Staff/2014

Long Beach, Wash., also close

Long Beach, Wash., is another family fun zone, just 20 miles north of Astoria. Bonus: you get to drive over the Columbia River bridge to ride the carousel at Long Beach.

Don Ryan/AP Photo/2003

Astoria sunsets pretty, too

You don't need to drive to the coast to see a nice sunset at Astoria. The setting sun paints cloud-filled skies over the bridge connecting Oregon and Washington in Astoria,the oldest continually inhabited white settlement west of the Rockies.

Read answers from questions posed to Astoria's tourism experts.

Staff photo/2013

If you don't visit Astoria . . .

. . . you won't get to bite into one of these. Fresh fish tacos are among the favorites at the Astoria Coffeehouse Bistro. Astoria has become a hip riverfront destination . . . just read what those who live there say, if you don't believe it.
